name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: The Human Body

transcript.content: What d'you, what do you think about that? Sticking a, a, a fist up your arse?
Uh. Weren't meant to be, was it? I mean it's, it's not - you know. It's gonna do damage, innit? It's... it's like... you've gotta know when to stop putting stuff in a carrier bag.
And it's the same as that. Innit? 'Cause it rips.
Someone told me this recently at a party. A fascinating fact. Um, see what you think of it, Karl. He told me that apparently if you've got time on your hands you can put your
Fist inside someone else's arse. And then you can work your hand, very slowly, up through the person's body. Takes about two hours, apparently. And eventually-
It's what he told me. You can touch that person's heart.
Right. And it's like the most intimate thing you could ever do with someone else.
That's what he said. That's what that bloke said.

How could you touch their heart? One, the alimentary canal is about thirty foot long. So you'd have - either have to have thirty - you'd have to be Mr Tickle, right - or you'd have to be rolling up the alimentary canal as you go, like a
Like a stocking on a pole, right.

And then when you get up there, how can you touch the heart? You'd have to rip through the oesophagus which would kill them. Okay. If the, if the arm going all the way up their alimentary canal the wrong way didn't kill them.
But I like the idea of someone saying that to a loved one.
"Alright, love. Love, little surprise for you. Um. The kids are at your mother's."
"Um, I've, I've put the - the phone's off the hook."
They, actually they'd better be out for four, because I'm going to need to get it back out again.
Imagine the, the doorbell goes, you gotta sign for a package.
Who told you that at a party? A psychopath?
I don't know! You see, he's, he, and then he was convinced it was true because he, he went online to try and, uh, even though were at a party, he found a computer-
-and started typing in "fist, heart, stuff" and I said, you better delete that-
In case the person whose computer it is finds out.
Yeah. Also, if the aim is to touch the heart, right? Go via the mouth, it's shorter.
Let's pop it down the mouth. Yeah. Karl, thoughts?
I mean, there's getting to know people...
I mean, you know how people say, oh, you shouldn't use a toilet with the door open, and all that, because it ruins...
Like, knowing too much everything. But that, for me... Where do you go from there?
Ricky makes a strange little noise
But I've - you know me. I mean I've got nothing against, uh, gays and that-
-but I've - they puzzle me to this day. There's still things that happen when, uh, I go, "What is all that about?"
I went to what's-her-name... Harley Street. I went for a, a check-up.

It's like it's the top doctors innit. I've never been before.All posh buildings and that. Uh, went up to the counter and said, uh, "Here to see the doctor." They said name, yep, yeah. It was ten minutes. Go and wait in the waiting room. Dead posh waiting room. Dead fancy. Big leather furniture and that.
Loads of magazines. I mean, like a, like a newsagents. In the middle of the room on a table, loads of them.
Coming in, because she was older than me, weren't she? So, to her-
How old was Mrs Battersby? She was older, she must be.
She was older, because I'm calling her Mrs Battersby. If she was my age, I'd probably say, "Oh, it's Susan," or whatever.
You call older people by their surname, don't you?
Uh, anyway, so she came in, right-
I dunno. I'm thinking of pictures at the wedding. Uh... I s'spose-
Why'd you have to go through other things to just have a memory?
How old do you reckon you were?
What, wha- I don't understand why you haven't got direct access to your memories.
How old do you reckon you were?
Your mum was older though, yeah?
You must have a vague idea of when this event was?
I'm thinking about it now. I'm thinking.
I'm picturing the picture of meself at this wedding,
And how old are you? What are you doing?
How were you at uh uh, but w-
I'd say I look about seven or eight, looking at the picture.
So Mrs Battersby is chatting away to you. You don't remember what she said, but you do remember having the conversation?
No, he doesn't remember it at all.
I don't remember the chat now!
Well then why are you telling me!
You must remember it 'cause you're telling us about it!
'Cause it's a memory! Me mam's reminded me of it.
Yeah but all it says it, oh, this is so far removed. This is hearsay that your mum said you spoke to a ghost once. You don't even remember the ghost-
Yeah, no, but you don't remember her!
Yeah, you remember the name only because your mum reminded you of it!
In a court of law, if there was a ghost
Court, they'd go "Hearsay! Thrown out of court."
You don't have a memory of Mrs Battersby.
No, look. I know that when I was a kid, I ate a beetle.
I ate a beetle because I thought it was licorice. Now I can't remember that, now.
You can't remember that but you're, you know it happened because your mother told you it happened.
Right. But the fundamental thing is that we can believe-
His memories! His memories are amazing!
We can believe, we can believe you ate a beetle, right, because that is something that could happen in real life.
What we're questioning is that you spoke to a ghost.
Just one of them standard beetles. Just little black shiny one.

The thing is right, couple of years ago, we were in The Ivy and the food came and there's a big blob of wasabi, right? It was like a a, a, um, got a called an oriental hors-d'oeuvre, right? And uh, I looked over at Karl and he started going-
-drinking water. I said, "What have you done?" He said, "I ate that." I said, "That was a blob of wasabi." He said, "I thought it was one mushy pea."
That's a classy restaurant if they're serving one mushy pea.
Well they do that, don't they?
Small portions. Sort of trendy, innit?
Yeah! I love the fact that it's the- exactly the same thing. They've swapped beetle for wasabi-
-and licorice for pea. I, but, you see thing, you see something you think-
It's a good job you remember that anecdote, though, because he doesn't.
Exactly! Yeah. In years to come he'll be going, "Ate some wasabi once."
"Well according to Ricky I did, yeah, I was in The Ivy. I thought, I thought it were a mushy pea.
So hang on, I just want to go back to Mrs Battersby
-this place was haunted, it was the most haunted place-
-but you've got no real evidence for it because even- even- you claim you had this encounter, you don't even remember it.
But you don't remember everything in life.
But you supposedly had a conversation with a ghost!
But I didn't know. When I was younger I didn't know it was a ghost.
But you remember the specifics of an ant walking around.
Oh! Yeah, so you thought, ah, so I see. If you'd have had the memory, it'd just be a nice old lady on the end of your bed all night.
Then I mentioned it, me mam was saying, "What do you mean, Mrs Battersby?
I mean, it- you know, there's only so much you can do. I mean, even in that film, there was a woman with three tits.
There's only- There's- Y'know I'm not talking about having like a shoe for a head.
I'm just talking about the weirdness
He's like a surrealist, he's amazing isn't he? like a shoe-
You'd like to see more three-titted women, is that what you're saying?
We'd all like to see that.
It doesn't matter, mix it up.
At least then it's a bit more of a surprise. What you're gonna get.
And it's a shame because it does make the world more interesting.
But what's more interesting than the world, than the natural diversity?
This is it, you're endlessly bored- you're endlessly bored by the world as it is, we're amazed here; we sit here amazed by these facts, by thinking about the cosmos, you're endlessly bored by it,
Always looking for something new, and weird, and alien.
Do you know, they- they've estimated, that there might be about 5 million species of animal, right?
There might be another 20 million - all insects. So they've- they've stuck it at about one, but they wouldn't be surprised if there's another 20 million species of insect.
No 'cause You start off with a big stuff, don't you? If someone comes along- I mean, I'm still surprised when they say things like we found a new duck and I think, well that's not hard to find.
If we're talking about bacteria I'd go well done, where did you find it?
No, that's the other way around.
No, I'd be annoyed that someone's- someone's not found it. If it's there- it's not my job to find new stuff.
But if someone's on the payroll,
And they're out there, try to find new species-
There's not- there's no one on the payroll.
And they go 'We've found a new llama' I'd go well, where is- what- wha- what- why have you missed this?
No, but it's harder to find- Attenborough, he's been out doing his job for years hasn't he?
He was excited that he found a small frog.
He found a frog, stuck it on his finger. Said 'I've been looking for that for ages.'
Did he check under the microwave, down the back of the couch?
He was chuffed. I was chuffed for him.
He'd been looking for it for ages
But now the thing is- respect due to him there.
His eyes aren't as good as they used to be.
He's been looking for it- he kept looking, I'd have given up if I was him
But he kept looking, he found it, there it was a little frog in the end of his finger.
It wasn't on his finger all along, was it?
I've got more respect for him, finding that-
Than someone else whose job it is to also be rooting 'round for new stuff, coming down the corner with an elephant saying, 'look what I've got, I've been looking for this.'
Yeah, but that's not what happened!
You haven't been looking hard enough!
They're- No one's looking for an elephant and has failed to find it!
They don't know what they're looking for.
You are now annoyed with these people who are on the payroll looking for elephants.
Yeah. By definition they're not looking for new species because they don't know they exist. It's a surprise.
No one goes out and they go: 'What you looking for today?' 'I dunno'  'say a letter.' 'D?' 'Duckling. Let's look for a new duck.' 'Where you gonna look?' 'Pond.' 'All right.'
I know, But sometimes it's the slightest thing. I mean, we've done a lot of insects-
Yes it is, yes it is, yeah.
But they go- 'I've found a spider with, like, a- an orange leg or a fish that swims upside down.' It's like, put it the right way up!
I mean, it's- it's not worth it. It's not worth noting. I'd say what's- It's got to be a dramatic difference.
